rsbNotes.title: Isa 56–66
rsbNotes.text: 56:1–66:24 These prophecies are addressed to the exiles returned from Babylon before the rebuilding of the temple in 520 b.c. (64:8–12). They still suffer from idolatry, hypocrisy and indifference. Isaiah prophesies concerning their responsibilities toward the coming glorious kingdom and the certainty of its arrival.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:1
rsbNotes.text: 66:1 See theological note “The Spiritual Nature of God” on next page.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:3–4
rsbNotes.text: 66:3–4 The Lord hates empty religious expressions as much as paganism (Jer. 7:21–23 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:3
rsbNotes.text:
66:3 kills a man. This may be an allusion to child sacrifice (cf. Jer. 7:31; Ezek. 23:39).

breaks a dog’s neck. Only certain animals were prescribed for sacrifice. The dog was not even permitted for food (56:10 note; Lev. 11:26).

pig’s blood. See 65:4.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:5
rsbNotes.text:
66:5 who hate you. The opposition reflected in ch. 65 between God’s servants and nominal Israel has intensified.

Let . . . joy. Such an expression of praise by rebellious people is hypocritical righteousness.

shall be put to shame. Humiliation is the fate of the persecutors. See v. 10 for the fate of the persecuted.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:7
rsbNotes.text: 66:7 Before . . . birth. The birth of the new community will be sudden, and no human effort will contribute to it. Christ laid the foundation of the church in His lifetime, especially in the week of His death and resurrection (John 2:19).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:9
rsbNotes.text: 66:9 The purposes of God will not be frustrated, or begun only to be left unfinished.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:11
rsbNotes.text: 66:11 nurse . . . satisfied. See note 60:16.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:12
rsbNotes.text: 66:12 her. Mother Jerusalem (vv. 8, 10).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:13
rsbNotes.text: 66:13 mother. The Lord likens His tender love to that of a mother.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:15
rsbNotes.text: 66:15 fire . . . whirlwind. These depict lightning and storm clouds respectively (Deut. 33:26; Ps. 18:10; Jer. 4:13), common accompaniments of God’s appearance (10:17, 18; 29:6; Ezek. 32:6–8 note). Isaiah prayed for God to come in this way to bring judgment (64:1–3).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:16
rsbNotes.text: 66:16 sword. The Lord appears as a warrior (27:1; 34:5; Rev. 19:11–18). See notes 9:6; 13:4; 40:10; 42:13.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:17
rsbNotes.text: 66:17 gardens . . . pig’s flesh . . . abomination. See v. 3; 65:2–5.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:18
rsbNotes.text:
66:18 their works and their thoughts. Probably the works and thoughts of those to be gathered.

all nations and tongues. There will be universal acknowledgement of the Lord’s kingdom (Zech. 8:23; Rev. 7:9, 10).

glory. This is God’s glory in His temple (Ezek. 11:22, 23; 44:4).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:19
rsbNotes.text:
66:19 sign. This “sign” is probably remarkable acts of judgment on the false worshipers as the remnant is delivered from among them.

survivors. The true worshipers who survive persecution (v. 5; Matt. 24:9–14) bring God’s glory to the nations (v. 18).

Tarshish. See note 23:5.

Pul, and Lud. In North Africa.

Tubal. South of the Black Sea in modern Turkey (Ezek. 38:2, 3; 39:1).

Javan. The people of Asia Minor or Greece (Ezek. 27:13, 19; Joel 3:6).

declare . . . nations. The Gentiles will submit themselves to the Lord and rejoice in His mighty acts (24:16 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:20
rsbNotes.text: 66:20 all your brothers. The Gentiles will bring dispersed Israel back to the temple (43:5; 60:4, 9; Rom. 11:11–14).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:22
rsbNotes.text:
66:22 new heavens . . . new earth. See note 65:17 (cf. 2 Pet. 3:13; Rev. 21:1).

your offspring and your name. The people of God will never again suffer reproach, but will enjoy everlasting glory (43:1 note; 65:18, 19; cf. Jer. 31:35, 36).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:23
rsbNotes.text: 66:23 new moon . . . Sabbath. There will be universal worship of God at His appointed time (cf. Zech. 14:16).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 66:24
rsbNotes.text: 66:24 worm . . . fire. Jerusalem’s garbage dump became symbolic of perpetual punishment and anguish (30:33 note; Mark 9:47, 48).
